MINUTE ORDER. Defendants' motion to stay, docket no.  53  in Case No. C23-97, is RENOTED to the third Friday after it was filed, namely August 11, 2023. In light of defendants' motion to stay, defendants' motion to dismiss, docket no.   36  in Case No. C23-97, is RENOTED to the same day as the motion to stay, namely August 11, 2023. Plaintiffs' motion to certify class, docket no.  17  in Case No. C23-97, is STAYED pending the Courts ruling on defendants' motion to dismiss , in which they contend that the Court lacks jurisdiction. The parties in Case Nos. C23-535, C23-620, C23-5374, and C23-5378 shall meet and confer and file, on or before August 11, 2023, an identical Joint Status Report in each case setting forth the  parties' respective views concerning whether those actions should be stayed pending resolution of Mercado v. Miller, Case No. 23-16007, currently before the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The parties are further DIRECTED to keep the Court apprised of any additional related cases that have been, or are in the future, filed in this District. Authorized by Judge Thomas S. Zilly. (MJV)

MINUTE ORDER. Defendants' motion to stay, docket no.  53  in Case No. C23-97, is GRANTED, and Case No. C23-97 is STAYED. Based on the agreement of the parties in Case Nos. C23-535, C23-5374, and C23-5378, those actions are also STAYED. In light  of the above rulings, and having reviewed the Joint Status Report, docket no. 15 in Case No. C23-620, the Court sua sponte STAYS Case No. C23-620 over plaintiffs objection. The parties are DIRECTED to file a consolidated Joint Status Report in each o f these actions within fourteen (14) days after resolution of Mercado v. Miller, Case No. 23-16007, which is currently before the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, or by June 14, 2024, whichever occurs earlier. The parties are fur ther DIRECTED to keep the Court apprised of any additional related cases that have been, or are in the future, filed in this District. The stipulated motion to extend the deadline for filing a responsive pleading or motion, docket no. 8 in Case No. C23-5378, is STRICKEN as moot. Authorized by Judge Thomas S. Zilly.  (MJV)

MINUTE ORDER: Having reviewed the parties' Joint Status Report in these cases, indicating that, on 11/6/2023, the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit heard oral argument in Mercado v. Miller, Case No. 23-16007, the Court DIRECTS  that these matters shall remain stayed and that the parties shall provide a Joint Status Report within fourteen (14) days after the Ninth Circuit issues a decision in Mercado, or by 12/31/2024, whichever occurs earlier. Authorized by Judge Thomas S. Zilly.  (MJV)

ORDER denying Defendants'  28   Motion to Stay.  The Court hereby EXTENDS the  deadlines set forth in its February 16, 2023  Order as follows: FRCP 26(f) Conference Deadline is now 4/17/2023,  Initial Disclosure Deadline is now  5/3/2023,   Joint Status Report is now due by 5/13/2023.   Signed by Judge Tana Lin. (LH)

MINUTE ORDER: On or before June 16, 2023, counsel in all three matters (C23-0097 TSZ, C23-0535 TSZ, and C23-0620 TSZ) shall meet and confer and file an identical Joint Status Report in each case addressing the described issues. The motion to certify class, docket no.  17 , and the motion to dismiss,  docket no.  36 , in Case No. C23-97, are RENOTED to June 16, 2023.  Authorized by Judge Thomas S. Zilly.  (LH)

case_data.name: Silvia Guevara Enriquez v. United States Citizenship and Immigration Services
case_data.plaintiff_description:
all individuals:
a) who filed, or will file in the future, an application with USCIS for a provisional unlawful presence waiver (Form I-601A or any successor form), and 
b) whose applications have been pending for at least twelve months from the date of filing
case_data.summary:
This is a case about the delays in processing times for provisional unlawful presence waivers in visa applications. On January 23, 2023, a group of immigrants filed this putative class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Western District of Washington. The plaintiffs sued the United States Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) and its director under Section 702 of the Administrative Procedure Act (APA). Represented by both private counsel and the American Immigration Council, the plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief.  

The plaintiffs were beneficiaries of approved family-based immigrant visa petitions. Noncitizen beneficiaries of approved immigrant visa petitions who are unlawfully present in and not lawfully admitted or paroled into the U.S. are not able to secure legal status and must appear at a consulate abroad in order to apply for issuance of an immigrant visa. They can then seek admission to the U.S. at a port of entry. They alleged that the defendants' delay in deciding their applications for a provisional waiver—a required step before they could be set for their consular appointment abroad—had left the plaintiffs and class members stuck in limbo. While they waited, the plaintiffs were unable to work and remained susceptible to removal from the U.S. The plaintiffs alleged that historically this step had typically taken four to five months, but that in fiscal year 2022 the median processing time reached 31.7 months.

The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants had violated the APA by taking an unreasonable amount of time to process their applications. The plaintiffs argued that the delays impacted human health and welfare because the plaintiffs were unable to seek employment or obtain lawful status in the U.S. The plaintiffs asked the court to apply the six factors identified by the D.C. circuit in Telecomms. Rsch. & Action Ctr. v. FCC to determine whether the agency's delay was unreasonable. Under that framework, the plaintiffs argued that: 

1) "Rule of Reason": USCIS did not follow a rule of reason in adjudicating provisional waiver applications. 

2) Statutory Benchmark: Congress had expressed that USCIS should adjudicate provisional unlawful presence waiver applications within 180 days. 

3&5) Prejudice and Harm to Health and Welfare Due to Delay: Much of this section of the complaint was redacted, but the plaintiffs asserted that class members had faced hardships due to the delays because they were unable to make plans due to the uncertainty surrounding their application. 

4) Competing Parties: USCIS had a history of prioritizing family unity and the delay in the applications had caused harm to the plaintiffs and their families because of the uncertainty they faced and fear of being separated. 

6) Unreasonable Delay Does Not Require Impropriety: The plaintiffs argued that the processing times of roughly three years were unreasonable and did not have to be the result of bad faith or other impropriety. 

The plaintiffs sought a declaration that the defendants violated the APA and an order compelling USCIS to decide the provisional waiver applications for the named plaintiffs within 30 days, and future applications within 180 days of filing. They also asked the court to certify a class defined as: “all individuals: (a) who filed, or will file in the future, an application with USCIS for a provisional unlawful presence waiver (Form I-601A or any successor form), and (b) whose applications have been pending for at least twelve months from the date of filing.”

On January 26, 2023 the case was assigned to Judge Tana Lin. The same day, the plaintiffs filed a separate motion to certify their class. 

This case was ongoing as of February 12, 2023.
case_data.summary_short: On January 23, 2023, a group of immigrants filed this putative class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Western District of Washington against the US Citizenship and Immigration Services and its director, alleging that delays in processing provisional unlawful presence waivers violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA). According to the complaint, average processing times exceeded 30 months in 2022. The plaintiffs sought a declaration that the defendants violated the APA and an order requiring them to process applications within the 180-day timeframe recommended by Congress. As of February 12, 2023, this case was ongoing.
case_data.summary_tiny: Group of immigrants file complaint against US Citizenship and Immigration Services over lengthy processing times for provisional unlawful presence waiver applications.

INTRODUCTION 
12 
1.  Plaintiffs are the beneficiaries of approved family-based immigrant visa petitions. The 
13 
petitions were filed either by U.S. citizens or U.S. lawful permanent residents. While Defendant 
14 
U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) has approved the immigrant visa petitions 
15 
filed on Plaintiffs’ behalf, USCIS’ unreasonable delay in deciding their applications for a 
16 
provisional waiver—a required step before they can be set for their consular appointment 
17 
abroad—has left Plaintiffs and class members stuck in a bureaucratic nightmare. They cannot 
18 
work and remain susceptible to removal from the United States while waiting for a decision on 
19 
their waiver applications. Without the timely historical processing that this step has normally 
20 
enjoyed (4-5 months), Plaintiffs and class members cannot finalize the process to become U.S. 
21 
lawful permanent residents. Plaintiffs seek a return to the historical processing times for their 
22 
applications. 
23

I-601A, “Application for Provisional Unlawful Presence Waiver” with Defendant USCIS.

26 
provisional waiver applications reached 31.7 months for Fiscal Year 2022 (October 1, 2021 –

10  LEGAL BACKGROUND 
11  Family-Based Immigrant Visas and Provisional Unlawful Presence Waivers 
12  16.  To become U.S. lawful permanent residents in a family-based category, Plaintiffs and 
13  class members must complete a two-step process.  
14  17.  First, a U.S. citizen or U.S. lawful permanent resident must file a petition with USCIS for 
15  an immigrant visa classification on behalf of their noncitizen relative using a Form I-130 Petition 
16  for Alien Relative. See 8 U.S.C. § 1154(a)(1); 8 C.F.R. § 204.2.  
17  18.  Second, if Defendant USCIS approves the petition, noncitizens who will consular process 
18  must apply to the State Department for an immigrant visa. See 8 U.S.C. §§ 1201(a), 1202(a); 
19  22 C.F.R. §§ 42.61-62.  
20  19.  Noncitizen beneficiaries of an approved immigrant visa petition who are (a) unlawfully 
21  present in the United States, and (b) not lawfully admitted or paroled into the United States, like 
22  Plaintiffs and class members, must appear at a consulate abroad in order to apply for issuance of 
23  an immigrant visa and then seek admission at a port of entry.  See 8 U.S.C. § 1201(a); 22 C.F.R. 
24  §§ 42.61-62  
25  20.  A noncitizen “unlawfully present” in the United States who has not been admitted or 
26  paroled is, with limited exceptions, ineligible to adjust status in the United States on the basis of

1  a family-based immigrant petition. 8 U.S.C. § 1182(a)(9)(B); 8 U.S.C. § 1255(a). A noncitizen is 
2  “deemed” to be unlawfully present if “present in the United States after the expiration of the 
3  period of stay authorized by the [DHS Secretary]1 or is present in the United States without 
4  being admitted or paroled.” 8 U.S.C. § 1182(a)(9)(B)(ii). 
5  21.  If the noncitizen departs the United States after being unlawfully present for more than 
6  180 days but less than one year without receiving the provisional waiver, they become 
7  inadmissible to the United States and are ineligible for a visa for three years. 8 U.S.C. 
8  § 1182(a)(9)(B)(i)(I). 
9  22.  If the noncitizen departs the United States after being unlawfully present for at least one 
10  year, without receiving the provisional waiver, they become inadmissible to the United States 
11  and are ineligible for a visa for ten years from their date of departure. 8 U.S.C. 
12  § 1182(a)(9)(B)(i)(II). 
13  23.  A consular officer cannot approve an immigrant visa if the officer knows that the 
14  applicant is ineligible to receive a visa. 8 U.S.C. § 1201(g). 
15  24.  Congress gave the DHS Secretary the exclusive authority to waive inadmissibility for 
16  unlawful presence for “an immigrant who is the spouse or the son or daughter” of a U.S. citizen 
17  or U.S. lawful permanent resident, if the Secretary determines that the U.S. citizen or U.S. lawful 
18  permanent resident spouse or parent of the immigrant would suffer “extreme hardship” if the 
19  immigrant is refused admission to the United States. See 8 U.S.C. § 1182(a)(9)(B)(v); 8 C.F.R. 
20  § 212.7(e)(3). The Secretary exercises this authority through Defendant USCIS. See 8 C.F.R. 
21  § 212.7(e)(3). 
22  25.  In 2013 and 2016, DHS, through its component Defendant USCIS, promulgated detailed 
23  regulations that permit certain individuals who are present in the United States to request from 
24  USCIS a provisional waiver of inadmissibility before departing the United States for consular

8  26.  When adjudicating provisional waiver applications, USCIS officers may issue a Request 
9  for Evidence (RFE) to applicants to obtain more information as to eligibility before issuing a 
10  decision, including, but not limited to, evidence of extreme hardship. For other types of filings, 
11  USCIS may provide up to 87 days to submit a response to an RFE. In keeping with the agency’s 
12  streamlining of the provisional waiver application process, Defendant USCIS sets a deadline of 
13  30 days for responses to RFEs issued in connection with Form I-601A applications. See 1 USCIS 
14  Policy Manual Part E, ch. 6, § F.3, chart & n.54. “USCIS will retain the 30-day RFE response 
15  period, because USCIS and DOS closely coordinate immigrant visa and provisional waiver 
16  application processing. The 30-day RFE response time streamlines USCIS processing, prevents 
17  lengthy delays at DOS, and allows applicants to complete immigrant visa processing in a timely 
18  manner.” 81 Fed. Reg. at 50258.

15  TRAC FACTORS AND UNREASONABLE DELAY 
16  45.  Courts often evaluate whether an agency’s delay is unreasonable by applying the six 
17  factors identified by the D.C. Circuit in Telecomms. Rsch. & Action Ctr. v. FCC (“TRAC”):  
18  (1) the time agencies take to make decisions must be governed by a ‘rule of reason’; 
(2) where Congress has provided a timetable or other indication of the speed with 
19 
which it expects the agency to proceed in the enabling statute, that statutory scheme 
may supply content for this rule of reason; (3) delays that might be reasonable in 
20 
the sphere of economic regulation are less tolerable when human health and welfare 
21  are at stake; (4) the court should consider the effect of expediting delayed action on 
agency activities of a higher or competing priority; (5) the court should also take 
22 
into account the nature and extent of the interests prejudiced by delay; and (6) the 
23  court need not ‘find any impropriety lurking behind agency lassitude in order to 
hold that agency action is unreasonably delayed.’ 
24 
25  Telecomms. Rsch. & Action Ctr. v. FCC, 750 F.2d 70, 80 (D.C. Cir. 1984) (citations omitted). See 
26  also Brower v. Evans, 257 F.3d 1058, 1068-69 (9th Cir. 2001).

2  46.  Defendant USCIS does not follow a rule of reason in adjudicating Form I-601A 
3  provisional waiver applications. The agency’s median processing time for the Form I-601A 
4  provisional waiver application has increased from under five months from Fiscal Years 2013 
5  through 2018 to 31.7 months for Fiscal Year 2022. The most recently available processing times 
6  show the Nebraska Service Center decides eighty percent of provisional waiver applications in 
7  34 months and the Potomac Service Center decides eighty percent in 39.5 months. 
8  47.  Defendant Jaddou acknowledges that USCIS processing times are unreasonable. On 
9  February 2, 2022 (almost a full year ago, and when processing times were shorter than they are 
10  today), at a briefing for stakeholders on the one-year anniversary of the Biden administration, 
11  Defendant Jaddou stated: “Let me be very clear. Our processing times are too long. There are no 
12  ifs, ands or buts about it.” Suzanne Monyak, USCIS director: Federal immigration funds 
13  ‘critical’ to agency, Roll Call (Feb. 2, 2022, 7:17 pm), https://rollcall.com/2022/02/02/uscis-
14  director-federal-immigration-funds-critical-to-agency/. 
15  48.  USCIS’ median processing time for provisional unlawful presence waiver applications 
16  has jumped from under 5 months for the six years from FY 2013 through FY 2018, to 8.7 months 
17  in FY 2019, 11.2 months in FY 2020, 17.1 months in FY 2021, and 31.7 months in FY 2022. 
18  These  substantial increases in processing times do not equate to a reasonable time frame for 
19  processing provisional waiver applications. Barrios Garcia v. DHS, 25 F.4th 430, 454 (6th Cir. 
20  2022) (concluding in the context of agency delays that “it [is] unhelpful to fixate on the average 
21  snail’s pace when comparing snails against snails in a snails’ race.”). 
22  49.  Congress has expressed its expectation that USCIS adjudicate an application for a 
23  provisional unlawful presence waiver within 180 days. “It is the sense of Congress that the 
24  processing of an immigration benefit application should be completed not later than 180 days 
25  after the initial filing of the application.” 8 U.S.C. § 1571(b).

4  (APA – Unreasonable Delay in Deciding Form I-601A Provisional Waiver Applications) 
5  77.  Plaintiffs reallege and incorporate by reference all allegations above as though fully 
6  restated here. 
7  78.  The APA provides for judicial review when a person is adversely affected by agency 
8  action. 5 U.S.C. § 702. Agency action includes an agency’s failure to act. 5 U.S.C. § 551(13). A 
9  court “shall compel agency action . . . unreasonably delayed.” 5 U.S.C. § 706(1). 
10  79.  Defendant USCIS has a non-discretionary duty to decide Plaintiffs’ pending Forms I-
11  601A provisional waiver applications. USCIS is required to give notice of an approval or denial 
12  for all properly filed benefits requests. See 8 C.F.R. § 103.2(b)(19) (defining procedures for 
13  notification of approvals); 8 C.F.R. § 103.3 (defining notification procedures for denials). More 
14  specifically, USCIS “will notify the [noncitizen] and the [noncitizen’s] attorney of record or 
15  accredited representative of the decision [on a Form I-601A] in accordance with 8 CFR 
16  103.2(b)(19).” 8 C.F.R. § 212.7(e)(9)(i) (emphasis added). “With due regard for the convenience 
17  and necessity of the parties or their representatives and within a reasonable time, each agency 
18  shall proceed to conclude a matter presented to it.” 5 U.S.C. § 555(b) (emphasis added). “[B]y 
19  using the term ‘shall’ in requiring that the courts compel action unlawfully withheld or 
20  unreasonably delayed, Congress imposed a mandatory duty in that regard.” Saini v. U.S. 
21  Citizenship & Immigr. Servs., 553 F. Supp. 2d 1170, 1176 (E.D. Cal. 2008). 
22  80.  Defendant USCIS’ duty to adjudicate an application is a discrete, ministerial act that 
23  applicants pay for in advance and that USCIS must complete within a reasonable time. USCIS 
24  set an appropriate fee for the application for unlawful presence waiver based on the statute. 
25  81 Fed. Reg. at 50260.
